docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE USING this space recently to de-scribe the miseries afflicting me since I stopped smoking 361 days ago, I have been inundated with expert opinion. Almost all the experts agree that the constant strangling sensation I suffer in neck and waist is not the result of a mysterious shrinkage of clothing, as I suppose, but is caused by food-fueled expansion of the fatty tissues. This strikes me as bunk. Is it sensible to suppose that a stomach might crave more food intake simply because a set of lungs with which it happened to be associated suddenly had its smoke cut off?
